comments.commentBody:
What a laughable comment, choosing to criticize Plato and Socrates now. Is there no end to the Greek vilification.

Alexander the Great did sack Persepolis but remember Persia burned Athens to the ground first, and invaded and plundered Greece several times. Alexander spread Hellenism, Greek values and culture, throughout the known world, and for that he should be applauded.

could it be European taxpayers are sick of flushing money down the toilet without account, especially considering the history of Greece's inability, over past 30 years, to make any meaningful reforms in pension system, land registry (only nation in Europe to not have one), rampant corruption and clientelism?

It comes down to this: "the reason the Eurocrats (IMF, Troika, et al) are driving such a hard bargain is that they find the relatively independent government of Greece to be highly unpalatable for their neo-liberal tastes." Jesse - Café Americaine

In other words…anyone who stands up to their demands is a threat to their authority.

David Stockman agrees with you: "By defaulting on its IMF loan, walking away from the troika bailout program and taking control of its insolvent domestic banking system, Alexis Tsipras and his band of political outlaws have shattered a giant illusion.
Namely, that the world’s debt serfs will endlessly and meekly acquiesce to whatever onerous, eleventh hour arrangements might be concocted by their official paymasters——even when these expedients are for no more noble or sustainable purpose than to forestall a Monday moring hissy fit among the gamblers in the world’s financial casinos."

Hissy fit - or fiscal hit…it's all the same thing.

I guess you missed the NYT article that had a chart showing that ALL OF THE PERSONAL SAVINGS IN GREECE add up to LESS than the total balance of the loans owed to the troika. Basically, to stay in the Euro means that the Greeks would have to surrender ALL of their national savings to the Euro banks and hedge funds. That does not sound like a good deal to me.

People go bankrupt. Companies go bankrupt. Countries go bankrupt. Time to move on.

Being in the biz, I can say there are times when "mike" is the right word and times when "mic" is preferable. The sentence, "Go to the mike at center stage" would be a good instruction to a speaker or auctioneer - but the sound engineer wants to "connect a cardioid mic into channel 6". I think when it is a component of a whole system, MIC will always be preferred - but when it is viewed as a thing of itself, a station, so to speak, then it is a MIKE.
The U.S. cannot even reform its Civil War era political and social attitudes in 150 years. Does anyone wonder why people are expecting Greece to reform their entire government and economy in 5 years?
No, its about the financiers and Euro elite who need to wag the dog to hide their greed and incompetence of the past decade.
It's not illegitimate. They borrowed it. They can't repay it. They need to go out of business as a country,

>>> he is trying to do what he was voted in to do. Not to do what you lot bloody want him to do.

You would have a point except that Merkel, Renzi and other European leaders are trying to do what their (far more numerous) voters want them to do, not what Tsipras wants them to do.

And like other US citizens most also work for said pensions. Maybe many people can save their safety net but it is almost impossible for a lost older generation that worked very diligently for their state level pension and are seeing it fly away as they retire. Those people, quite a few actually are completely stuck in a rut.
They'd have to register, but they are US citizens so if they are over 18 yes they could (and do) become voters.

Unlike other countries with distressed economies, Puerto Ricans can move to anywhere they want in the US. Seems like you're suggesting that they do just that. In addition to economic benefit, anyone moving to a state automatically becomes an eligible voter too? Unlike Greece, Puerto Ricans get social welfare, old age pensions, medicare and medicaid from the US as well as food stamps and other welfare benefits. Their safety net will not be frayed by government insolvency.

Why?  Have they imposed austerity, reforms on financial practices, or any other overreaching political demands in exchange for our taking the loans.  Have they demanded repayment of interest on their loans to the extent that our citizens are suffering.  I could go on, but I think you can see the point.  They lent money for their own reasons, not to impose their way of doing things on our country's political and financial, pension, social security systems, etc. to punish us for being so remiss as to send trillions of dollars on a war we couldn't afford - did they say we had to dismantle our "way of life" in order to pay back the interest on the loan?  This is the problem with the IMF loan, imagine our countrymen being told what to do in order to have taken or pay back the debt?  America has so much debt, but if the lender's started dictating terms to pay pack the interest now or else, Americans would be livid!  As are the Greek people.  Lending money does not naturally give the lender a lock on dictating the terms of one's way of life.  That's extortion.

After my father died in April, I was very upset as I realized that he probably was uncomfortable for several months but never told us. However, he chose to have the treatment he had. He chose to go to the hospital a week before he died. He fought hard for life, but we were lucky. He had a beautiful last day, surrounded by his family, and he died peacefully.

Take away some of the big airlines' landing slots and gate assignments.  They don't really need them anyway, the way they're colluding to limit flights, and who knows what small airlines might gain a toehold at LAX or O'Hare and actually provide some competition?

I agree.  If it were an open primary for the Democratic nomination then Zephyr Teachout would have clobbered Cuomo.  And who went to bat for Cuomo to solidify the Working Family Party's endorsement,  Bill DeBlasio.  And now he complains about Cuomo's governing.  He really has himself to blame for the outcome that exists currently.

Though the article is not clear on this, the issue certainly is not one about upstate versus downstate Democrats.  Upstate Democrats have long loathed Andrew Cuomo and anyone who doubts it should just look at the map of support for Teachout versus Cuomo in the primary.  In upstate counties like Albany, where his fellow state workers know him as an arrogant, self-aggrandizing bully, more than 80% of Democrats voted for Teachout.  The New York Times has too often stereotyped  Cuomo's lack of support upstate as being a result of the Safe Act, but this is nonsense and seems to come straight from Cuomo's PR machine.  Teachout is also in favor of gun control.  The fact is that Cuomo is bad for Democrats (and other New Yorkers) statewide.
What choice are you being denied here?  The choice to discriminate with society's approval?  Is that the choice you lost?  I don't get it.

A lot of good work, obviously. But I am not sure a true professional writes a story about what a true professional he is--if the job is too much for him, I am sure many others would like it and not complain for having to do what Anthony Lewis said he would have to do--and what Lewis and Greenhouse did so well.  Without complaints.

One can always tell a true professional: he (or she) rises to the deadline.

Congrats on a great job; will you follow up with an introspective piece at the end of the summer on this momentous term, and a look ahead to the next one?

The damage to Greece has already been inflicted.  Haven't you read about it?  The original private holders of the debt have been paid off and relieved of participation; now it's governments and quasi-governments like the ECB who hold the debt.  Unlike when they have something to gain for themselves, they are unwilling to admit the debt is uncollectible.  They seem to be willing to drive Greece into permanent depression as long as they extract the blood.

A very attractive policy plan for the EU would be to take a write-down of the Greek debt, try to compensate the holders of that debt, while as gently as possible, usher Greece out the door. Admit the mistake, that Greece was not nearly ready for "prime-time" and try to clean up the mess as well as possible. The trick is to inflict as much damage as needed on Greece so as to convince other observing Euroleftists in other countries that this is not a good course, while not making it so tough that there is major violence or takeover by totalitarian governance, or Russian control. The ideal course, of a mature Greek Government living up to its promises, appears a fantasy.

Dan, obviously you don't have all of the info that you need. The "Greeks" have been asking for the EU to allow them to move on with restructuring their loans in order to create the necessary infrastructure for job creation, and to be able to pay off their loans. The problem is that EU (Merkel) is playing the game of the mega banks, and the investors in the Turkish tourism, that they are insisting that the Greeks make the Greek islands not affordable, and the Greek army a joke. The Greek government repeatedly asked if the EU will fortify the borders with EU led army forces, but no one is stepping up to agree to that. The Greek government has offered to pay off the debt with a reduced rate as originally agreed, but now with the rest of the EU members in trouble as well they (Merkel) does not want to create a precedence. And the most important fact is that the Greeks live on 300 euros a month! YES a whole household! And part of the demand is to reduce the pensions!! really? by how much? Who can live on that kind of income?

I am with Europe, and I would vote yes to the referendum if only the EU was more reasonable.

I have not heard anything in the press or in speeches by Greek leaders recently talking about how they are most concerned about unemployment and lack of economic growth in their country.  All I hear about is pensions ( you do know that the minimum social security payment in the USA is  pretty lousy as well) and how they can't seem to get rich people to pay their taxes.  Residence of Greece only pay 30% of GDP in taxes.  Countries such as  France and Germany pay around 40% and the other PIGS nations average over 35%

My problem with the Greece position is they are not interested in dealing with their biggest problem -  an unemployment rate of 25%.  If they would present an approach which emphasized getting people back to work and pushing their debt problems to a later time they could get a lot of traction with the European community.  Instead they keep insisting on a free lunch now and appear at least in the press with only being concerned with pension benefits of their government workers.

This is a lifeline in the same way that accepting a mafia loan is a lifeline: it buys you a bit of time, but postpones the inevitable catastrophe. And there is no bankruptcy court to help Greece out. They are sucked into a cycle of endless borrowing to service the interest on previous loans; any sane society would try and find an appropriate solution for their situation, instead of giving the banks free reign. The solution to Greece has to be political. There needs to be an agreement to tie repayment to production and exports -- which give both sides an incentive to encourage a Greek recovery. At the moment, Greece is a cash cow for the private banking institutions who are ultimately funding and profiting from this fiasco.

It's irresponsible for a privileged academic like Mr. Krugman to goad Greek citizens into cutting their lifeline. He claims that devaluation couldn't create that much more chaos than already exists. How does he know that? In Argentina, following a similar economic meltdown, the carteneros took to the streets to collect trash in order to survive; they still work there in large numbers today. There's no way of knowing how bad things could get in Greece. There's some hope, or at least there's time, to work on economic problems if they stay with the EU. And at the very least, the Greek people will have basic necessities during that time. To phone in a recommendation for ordinary Greeks to sever ties to Europe "to pave the way for eventual recovery," is cavalier and callous. Or, maybe Mr. Krugman hopes to join the drama when Tsipras paints his words on a banner.

Greece was lent far more than it EVER could repay. Bankers knew this, and did it anyway expecting a bail out by the tax payers of the EU. The rich and powerful of Greece took this money away, out of the country and left the people of Greece holding the bag.

This is yet another crime by rich banks and rich criminals.

>>> To be always on the receiving end of largess is a terrible burden for Greece. It would be far better to forget, (not forgive) the debt that Greece owes

Ah yes, owing money is a terrible, terrible burden for me too. My credit card companies should simply forget the money I owe them. Ideally, they would do this month after month after month!

>>> These days we are not dealing in gold or silver, merely electrons.

They're no less real for being electrons.

I have been both a borrower and a lender, a renter and a landlady. I know that when money is owed there is a huge amount of resentment. Friendship is very difficult to maintain when one owes another. This is true whether on the smallest scale of person to person or the very large scale of one nation to another.
To be always on the receiving end of largess is a terrible burden for Greece. It would be far better to forget, (not forgive) the debt that Greece owes, not to mention Italy, Spain, and all the other EU countries that are in debt to the IMF.

The Financial nabobs of the EU and the IMF have to take a look at what money really is. These days we are not dealing in gold or silver, merely electrons.
The European creditors have already overplayed their hand.

that's in addition to the 53% already given by the banks when the troika assumed it?
The Italians, using austerity for its own recovery, have already said that they did not institute the policies they did simply in order to ensure that Greece wouldn't have to. Ireland, too. Partnership runs both ways.

>>> And if a nation is one's partner, surely one doesn't ask it to starve itself in order to feed the well-fed.

Illogical. The Germans feed themselves through their economic success, not by being fed by starving Greeks.

What I would like to see: an offer from the "troika" which would involve some forgiveness of debts. After all, isn't Greece a full partner in the EU? And if a nation is one's partner, surely one doesn't ask it to starve itself in order to feed the well-fed.
Hint: When someone offers you money to repay creditors, the money winds up with the creditors, not to you.

"The Greek population has received almost none of the so-called "bail out" monies."

If so, what the Greek state made with all the money (320 billion Euro) lent in the past? Not given to the Greek population? Why then the population has voted their governements?

http://www.debtclocks.eu/public-debt-and-budget-deficit-of-greece.html

Yes, it actually is about "liars' poker" - but there is a confusion about who are the lairs.  The Greek population has received almost none of the so-called "bail out" monies.  Instead the Greek government has simply been a conduit to get money and then pay the banks who made the original bad lending decisions.  When the loans went bad, the banks have demandedd - and so far, with the exepcetion of Iceland, recived the money to make them whole while shifting the costs to other people.  This is the actual lairs' poker.

This is not true.  You talk of goodwill; there was none; just some pity and a pat on the back by those who caused GDP to drop by 25%.  Tsipras has been the most honest in this whole deal.  The EU bums broke Greece.  And when Greece rejected the EU stupidity (tactics most respected economists also reject), then the Germans, who paid the bailout money to save German and French banks, complain.  It is the EU and German leaders who have no credibility.

The Greeks were dealt a bad hand by the last bailout but have done little to help their cause in the past 6 months.   Unfortunately Tsipras hired a game theorist to get a better deal and all that ended up happening is that Greece destroyed any goodwill they had in the EU.  The Greeks thought their crazy madman approach would cause the other side to blink, but instead it made Tsipras look and be treated like a child.   The Greeks have no credibility and until they purge Syriza from power, they are going to go no where with the EU.
